MR. O'CONNELL AND THE IRISH GOVERNMENT.
EXCLUSION OF WARRANT (NAVAL) OFFICERS FROM COURT.
The House of Commons met this day exclusively for the purpose of receiving Petitions on the great question of REFORM.
THE IRISH GOVERNMENT AND MR. O'CONNELL.
The hon. Member said, that he concurred in the prayer of all these Petitions, with the exception of that which called for a Repeal of the Union.
PARLIAMENTARY REFORM — SIT TINGS OF THE HOUSE.
APOLOGY FOR THE USE OF AN IMPROPER TERM.
THE LOUD CHANCELLOR, AND THE COMMISSIONERS IN LUNACY.

The Petitioners complained, that although South Shields contained 16,000 inhabitants, there were not more than 100 persons who had a vote for the County, because the greater part were leaseholders under the Bishop of Durham.
The Petitioners also expressed their pleasure at the late change in his Majesty's Councils, but on that the hon. Member said he could not agree with them.
TAXES ON THE DIFFUSION OF KNOWLEDGE.
PROCLAMATIONS OF THE LOUD LIEUTENANT OF IRELAND.

The hon. Gentleman took the opportunity of expressing his approbation of the conduct of his Majesty's present Government in respect to Ireland, and his hope that their measures would be attended with success.
